description: From Old English sċeaga, scaga. Cognate with Old Norse skógr (“forest, wood”), whence Danish skov (“forest”). Doublet of scaw.

entries.meaning: (dated, dialectal) A thicket; a small wood or grove.
examples: The snows are fled away, leaves on the shaws, / And grasses in the mead renew their birth,

entries.meaning: (Scotland) The leaves and tops of vegetables, especially potatoes and turnips.
